commands.description: Selects 'my_database' to use for subsequent operations.

commands.command: CREATE TABLE users (id INT AUTO_INCREMENT PRIMARY KEY, name VARCHAR(100), email VARCHAR(100));
commands.description: Creates a 'users' table with id, name, and email columns.

commands.command: INSERT INTO users (name, email) VALUES ('John Doe', 'john@example.com');
commands.description: Adds a new user named 'John Doe' with the email 'john@example.com'.
Retrieves all data from the 'users' table.

commands.command: UPDATE users SET email = 'john.doe@example.com' WHERE name = 'John Doe';
commands.description: Updates the email of 'John Doe' to 'john.doe@example.com'.

commands.command: DELETE FROM users WHERE name = 'John Doe';
ALTER TABLE users ADD COLUMN age INT;
commands.description: Adds an 'age' column to the 'users' table.

commands.command: SELECT * FROM users JOIN orders ON users.id = orders.user_id;
commands.description: Combines data from 'users' and 'orders' tables based on user ID.

commands.command: SELECT * FROM users WHERE email LIKE '%@example.com';
commands.description: Retrieves users with email addresses ending in '@example.com'.

commands.command: SELECT * FROM users ORDER BY name ASC;
commands.description: Retrieves users sorted by name in ascending order.

commands.command: SELECT COUNT(*) FROM users GROUP BY email;
commands.description: Counts users grouped by email addresses.

commands.command: SELECT email, COUNT(*) FROM users GROUP BY email HAVING COUNT(*) > 1;
commands.description: Finds email addresses that appear more than once in the 'users' table.
Creates an index on the 'email' column of the 'users' table.
